title: Analyzing and Linking Big Data with Stratosphere
segmentation: They'll be talking about a project that has been going on in Berlin over the past couple of years, and the overall theme of the talk is how to link and analyze big data.
So a lot of things.
Looked about Big Data yesterday, so the story here.

In partly is that cheaper computational storage plus cloud computing are enabling economies of scale, and they're making big data analysis feasible at the same time, there is a wealth of open source software to do big data analysis, which lowers significantly the bar of entry for various companies.
Big Data is expected to have.
June Bugs in a couple of fields.
So for example, for scientific science will say and so at the next decade the way a scientist is going to come.
Hypothesis is going to be through Interactive Data exploration and at the same time for many businesses that operate on web scale.
Success in business is really dictated by the ability to quickly draw insights from the data.
Now the good thing about analytics is that so the more computers you give me, I will find easily more data to analyze or I will find a way to run a deeper analysis on that data.
So analytical workloads scale inversely with costs, so a major silence in this space is big data analytics and another silence is creating the economic initiatives for that.
So essentially creating an App Store for data information marketplaces where data can be exchanged.
Sold and bought as a resource.
So in one project that I.
We talked about yesterday that we are involved in in Berlin.

We're exploring really this information marketplace vision, so we're beginning with two diverse data pools, one that contains the evolving history of the web and a small data pool with financial and statical data.
And we're looking on how you can easily link this diverse tables together and run analysis on this data pools.
Using a cold framework and a common programming language.
Now this enables really many applications.
So for example, a company can do sentiment.
All market analysis so it can link data between blogs and Twitter streams with demographics and so on.
Home buyer would link data from Energy Company data plus demographics data to find out you know what is the mineral consumption in this area.
You can do traffic analysis and so on.
Now a couple of more photos, so for us.
Big data does not refer only to the three V's or the really the volume of data, but it actually also refers to new applications or queries.

So one observation is that nowadays people don't really want to run the traditional data warehousing queries that they have been using databases for, but they really need to go beyond that, so they really will really want to run complicated.
Algorithms machine learning on substantial volumes of data, a second operation, and this has to do the ecosystem of data management research.

So for many years, data management had a few key players, and as a researcher you know the best thing you could hope for is come up with a great algorithm that someone in Microsoft Oracle would pick up eventually after 10 years and put in the product.
So this is changed.
And this has changed primarily due to the popularity of the Hadoop Open source Framework.
At the same time, Hadoop has major shortcomings with respect to ease of use, efficiency and so on.
So the result is that in the data management research ecosystem, there are several projects going on right now that are rethinking data management.
Other mostly parallel scale.
And as all of these systems mature and go.
I'm hyped product.
Let's say they need to tackle hard and novel problems.
So one classic problem that comes up in data management is how to create, how to provide a declarative and easy programming language to the user and be able to execute things efficiently underneath.
So one of these systems that is being developed in Berlin.
Where is stratosphere?
Stratosphere is a research project.
It's a written research project between three universities and five research groups.
Within this universities in the Berlin area.
Building infrastructure for Big data analytics and essentially the one single species that you can think of it as a bridge between the parallel relational DBMS is an the MapReduce worlds.
So we are researching things like how do functional languages intersect with data parallelism, and of course how to re Architect the whole system to fit in this massively parallel scale.
The system is open source, you can download it, it is under the Apache license.
We will even provide a bit of support and it is currently used by a few universities and research institutes across Europe and the world.
So a little bit about the system architecture, so through.
This here is a query processor that runs on top of an infrastructure as a service cloud.
And although Stratosphere, you can run queries on a diverse variety of data pools.

Internally, the system has three layers, so on the top most layer you have a declarative high level query language which gets compiled into an intermediate representation, which we call the Pact programming model, which is a new programming model.
Then this passes through the optimizer then gets compiled to something that can be executed.
In the cloud.
Stratosphere so really on the top part of the project there are people that are looking at a variety.
Of use cases, so one use case here in the left is management of climate data, so these people want to validate and compare different climate models.
For example to predict monsoons and so on.
The characteristics of this data is that first of all it's huge because you can really make it grow very fast by playing with the resolution of space and time.
So here for example collecting data for Germany.
With a 2 kilometer resolution and three months time results in the one hour time resolution for three months results in 10 terabytes.
So you can imagine doing that for a larger region and more time so it really scales at the same time.
This data is quite structure, so it's quite similar to the data that was really the sweet spot for relational databases.
The other two use cases are, so the first one is text mining, so this is really about managing.
Unstructured data and the other one is data cleansing on linked open data.
So the idea here is that we are developing a platform that we're trying to keep general enough to support a variety of use cases ranging from very structure to very unstructured data.
At the top of the stratosphere, stock sits a query language that we call metal.
So this is a Dick.
Relative language that operates on Jason objects.
It was inspired by the IBM Job well language.

The focus here was to really make this as flexible as an extensive list possible, and the reason is that our benchmark is is these three use cases that are quite diverse, so we want to make it really easy for people to put in new libraries and integrate them with the language syntax and out of Oaks.
It provides information, provides operators for information, information extraction, data links and so on.
And we're really looking at incorporating time in the language is a first class concept.
At the same time, at the bottom level of Stratosphere.
It's it's never alone with his apparel execution engine, so nephila taxes inputs this directed acyclic graphs of tasks.
So if you're familiar with Microsoft's triad, it is quite a similar concept.
So so when you go and execute this kind of direct, basically graph all the magic has already happened, the parallelization has happened.
You don't look at, you don't see that as a programmer, but my point here is that.
First of all, our software is built from scratch that is not based on Hadoop or something and it is designed to be highly scalable.
It is designed to exploit the cloud characteristics and it permits a couple of.
Things that are not possible in Hadoop for example, permits well people pipelining in databases, which can really give you a performance boost.
At the middle layer, Stratosphere sits a new programming model that we developed, so this is internal.
If you if you choose to.
Your program in this high level query language you will not see this, but we can also write your program in this programming model.
For example, when you are implementing a new library.
So this is a dataflow program model, so this side effect free and the reason for that is to enable massive parallelism.

And essentially if you're familiar with our reduce, you can think of it as a generalization of the MapReduce model, so the centered around the concept of 2nd order functions, and besides map and reduce it provides you with further further of these function signatures here, for example with MapReduce Mathson Co groups, for example code groups, generalization of it use 2 dimensions.
So this makes it for example, lazy to write things that are quite tricky to do in MapReduce.
For example, you can easily write things like join, so relational queries that will be actually executed as efficient as an apparel database.
So the good thing about having this architecture this layer dark?
It takes around this part.
Programming model is that we can sort of bridge the gap between relational database and map reduce by actually having a query optimizer.
So here.
These two little trees here are our two programs in this packed model and the important thing so this both implement page rank.
So the important thing is that these two are two different MapReduce Hadoop limitations that are in two different libraries and perform differently for different datasets.

The good thing about Stratosphere is that you will write your program once and the optimizer itself will automatically pick one of these two implementations with first of all, it frees you as a programmer for having from having to think about these things, and second, it enables really orders of magnitude faster execution.
Ongoing research and strategy.
There is a first.

We are developing technique that is a hybrid of database technologies and compiler technologies to take this programs and so we run study code analysis over these programs and discover properties that enable us to reproduce most of the optimizations that their relation optimizer does without actually exposing sequel with the user.
Second major research team.
Is actually supporting iterations, so most analysis programs are not a simple pipeline of tasks, right?
So most non trivial stuff willing to do have some kind of recursion or iteration machine learning graph algorithms all of this.
So right now the state of the art for that is quite limited.
There are for example specialized systems like Google's Pregel that expose a different programming extra.
Obstruction to the programmer.
So for example graph abstraction there that can do that can perform really well on very limited tasks.

But the problem is that in a real world, in a real use case where you have some kind of information extraction and then you need to run a machine learning algorithm, then you need to do some post processing.
You need to bounce around between a couple of systems.
You need to use a workflow management system to orchestrate things and so on.
So what we saw with the prototype and a paper is that you can actually do all of these things uniformly within.
One system exposing only one programming abstraction and without having a performance hit.
OK, so to summarize, I talked a little bit about a project called Dope in the beginning I covered it all so yesterday in the breakout session.
So the goal of DOPA is to bootstrap information economy by providing information marketplaces and bringing and bring together very heterogenous data pools and link them.
It enables single sign analytics over this data bulls we're flexible and uniform programming language.
Stratosphere is really our technical infrastructure for doing.
Data analytics so it is it pushes the map reduce paradigm forward is it is a new system built from scratch and we're using it in several initiatives across Europe for several research projects.
So for education also and so on.
A few acknowledgments.
Low price funded by FP7.
Stratospheres funded from the German Research Council and the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.
We have a few partners in these projects spanning across Europe.
And that's it.
So this is our.
Website you can go find more information there.
You can find the research papers, documentation downloads, there's a mailing list if you want to use them, get support.
If you're using Twitter, we have a very negative account.
Thank you.
Do you expect that there's overhead?
Instead of using plain and now it's actually faster.
So the idea is that it's supposed to be quite a bit faster.
So for example, one major thing in Hadoop is that you need to write your data and distributed file system every time before doing an aggregation.

So in Stratosphere actually the optimizer makes that choice depending on the size of the characteristics of your data, so it has the potential to be really orders of magnitude faster, especially in cases.
Where you get intermediate results that are, let's say, larger than your input datasets.
So we have seen that many many times.
